Although Beria was not the official leader of the Soviet Union, he was part of a Triumvirate, which included Malenkov and Molotov, and he was said to possess a great deal of power, due to his position in the Triumvirate and as Minister of the Interior. While he had become known worldwide as a kind of executioner feared by Stalin himself, the latter undertook very liberal reforms: the transfer of the Gulag system to the Minister of Justice, the political release of more than a million people, the arrest of Stalinist trials such as the White Coat Conspiracy or the Mingrelian case. Worse, Beria promised to unite the German people if the new government was neutral and demilitarized. This surprised the whole world, but Beria was never anything but an opportunist looking for more power and these reforms are once again the proof.

On June 17, 1953, riots took place in the German Democratic Republic due to the food crisis, over-industrialization and the desire of the Soviet leadership to make Germany a neutral and democratic state. The situation worsened when the American Sector Radio in West Berlin reported the events in Berlin. The crowd seized several important buildings and it became urgent to settle the situation immediately.

We have just received a call from East Germany, they are undergoing a large-scale revolt and because of Beria's actions, we must act quickly before it is too late. Some of the hardest members propose that we send our tanks to the region and that we put Wilhelm Pieck in power, others, more moderate, propose that we help the East German government to suppress the movement and that we install a compromise person named Walter Ulbricht, and finally others propose that we install Otto Grotewohl as head of the government and that he concedes to some necessary reforms.

After the events in East Berlin and the actions he took, Beria found himself even more surrounded by enemies. A conspiracy began to be organized, consisting of Molotov, Khrushchev, Zhukov and part of the army and even Malenkov, who was theoretically his most loyal and powerful ally.

On June 26, 1953, Beria was summoned to a meeting of the Presidium and suddenly Khrushchev launched a scathing attack on Beria, accusing him of being a traitor and a spy in the pay of the British secret service. All other members immediately launched their attacks. Completely surprised, Beria asked Malenkov for support. Malenkov lowered his head and pressed a button under his desk and Zhukov and a group of armed officers entered the room and arrested Beria. It seems that Beria was executed on December 23, 1953 and pleaded on his knees before collapsing to the floor and crying. His death now meant a new internal struggle between party members. It remains Nikita Khrushchev, representing the more reformist faction of the party and the Stalinist faction, with the personalities of Malenkov and Molotov.

As promised by Beria, and with the agreement of the leaders of the West, Germany is now united and demilitarized. In order to avoid an escalation of tension, it was decided that the new government would remain neutral in this conflict. If the whole world welcomes this achievement, it makes the people in the Kremlin angry.

The intelligence service under the orders of Beria, the MKVD, has just learned with amazement that the members of the party and the Politburo seem to coordinate with the Red Army to prepare something against the power in place. It is already too late to counter them, but we must prepare for the worst.

In this beautiful morning, it is with amazement that we can see tanks walking around in various places of $CAPITAL$ and soldiers captured MKVD agents. However, the main target of this coup is Lavrentiy Beria but he is still untraceable. Soldiers loyal to Zhukov would later learn from an MKVD agent that Beria had been briefed and prepared forces loyal to him in the south of the country and tried to arrest "Stalinists and brainless monsters". Even if the CPSU and the army regained control of the country, a new Civil War between conservatives and Beria will beginning.

A new Civil War has just broken out and we, the RRS, are going to play a primordial role in this conflict since we are going to have to choose a side. Either we stay loyal to Beria, or we go back to fight with the USSR, or we take advantage of this chance to fight for our independence.

The Civil War ended and it was a victory for the Beria camp. Trials began to be held against the plotters and members of the party and the army in general. To celebrate this victory, a big parade will be organized in $CAPITAL$.

The Civil War has ended and this is a victory for the conservatives. Faced with the betrayal of the MKVD, the service is completely purged and a new one is created, the KGB, which will be much more loyal to the interests of the party. Beria's supporters will be judged and those who managed to escape will be hunted down all over the world.

After a Civil War and work, a new constitution was adopted in the Soviet Union. The new constitution is much more liberal and elections are scheduled soon. We can say that there is a before and after Beria.

Today is the trial of Beria, this one is judged, among other things, of treason, sabotage, being a spy for the British services ... In short, the list is long and Beria is judged for the example and to show the way not to take.

Faced with the policy of De-Stalinization and the beginning of cultural thawing undertaken by Nikita Khrushchev, a coup attempt is underway. They gathered most of the Stalinists, that is, Molotov, Malenkov, Kaganovich, and so many others who joined them later who were dissatisfied with the direction taken by Khrushchev. They called a meeting in the Presidium to remove him. Although the majority of members were not present, the plotters represented the majority at that time. However, this coup d'√©tat could fail thanks to the support of the Minister of Defense and Marshal of the Soviet Union, Georgy Zhukov. It was enough to give the order and Zhukov and his armies came to intimidate them.

Although the Sovnarkhoz, meaning Economic Councils, is not in itself a new concept and had been applied before the establishment of economic planning by Stalin in 1932. However, Nikita Khrushchev revived this concept with the aim of decentralizing the economy by sector, headed by their respective ministers, with the creation of a network of territorial councils throughout the USSR. However, a short period of decentralization in the early years of the reform aimed at breaking the rigidly centralized sectoral management system that had been in place since the mid-1930s, led to the destruction of a single technical policy and the disintegration of economic ties in industry and agriculture.

On his 60th birthday in 1956, Zhukov received his fourth Hero of the Soviet Union award, making him the first person to receive this honor four times. He became the highest ranking military officer who was also a member of the Presidium of the Central Committee of the Communist Party. He then became a symbol of national strength. However, this worried the CPSU that he could organize a coup d'√©tat, these fears were further reinforced when Zhukov demanded that the political agencies of the Red Army report to him before the Party. Even if he remains faithful to Khrushchev, the risk is too great to do nothing.

With Khrushchev's rise to power, he began a cultural liberalization, which allowed some foreign films, books, art and music to be available to the population. Some previously banned writers and composers, such as Anna Akhmatova and Mikhail Zoshchenko, were brought back into public life, and books by some internationally acclaimed authors were published in millions of copies to satisfy the interest of readers in the USSR. Russian composers, performers and music listeners experienced a new openness in musical expression. Although the Thaw was seen as a period of openness and liberalization, Khrushchev continued to impose restrictions on these newfound freedoms.

In 1959, the American National Exhibition was held in $CAPITAL$ and the goal of the USA was to show the productivity and prosperity of the United States so that, in the long term, the Soviet Union would devote its resources to the development of consumer goods, and thus reduce the development of the Heavy and Military Industry. This had more unexpected results such as the spectacular consumption of Pepsi, a debate between Nixon and Khrushchev called afterwards "The Kitchen Debate", but especially the discovery of Corn by Khrushchev. Convinced that corn would solve the agricultural problems in the Soviet Union, he wanted to put it absolutely everywhere. We could try to convince him to calm down about this thing before he is ridiculed... again.

In order to give shelter to everyone, Khrushchev launches the massive construction of buildings, generally limited to 5 floors, at low cost. These buildings were designed to be optimized in all possible aspects. Whether it is the size of the rooms, the size of the rooms... even the stairs were studied so that the grandmother could not make too much effort. Faced with this generalization, the population began to give the name of Khrushchyovka to designate the buildings of 5 floors built at that time. However, this is only a temporary solution.

In 1961, Nikita Khrushchev will take a decision that will not please the party at all, that of removing the body of Stalin in the Mausoleum of Lenin.Although this was in the continuity of the De-Stalinization, the party members still respected Stalin and even among the population, this could cause some emotions and misunderstanding. Should we continue the destalinization or be more pragmatic.

After Stalin's death, a triumvirate was formed around Malenkov, Molotov and Beria. However, the power was actually held by Beria, through his position in the Triumvirate but also as Minister of the Interior. However, in order to maintain his power or even to take it. Faced with his liberal positions and the problems he generated in East Germany, a conspiracy was organized within the party, composed of Malenkov, Molotov, Khrushchev and Zhukov to get rid of him for good and will die on December 23 begging for his fate.

After the fall of Beria, an internal struggle within the party had begun to choose the new leader of the Soviet Union. There were two camps: the Malenkov faction, representing in a more general way, the Stalinist faction and the Khrushchev faction, perceived as more moderate. It is obvious that Khrushchev is especially more appreciated because potentially more easily influenced. We can always try to use our still dominant position to get him out.

Now that any form of opposition that is too dangerous has been eliminated. The party is still divided over who to trust as leader of the Soviet Union. There are two contenders: Georgy Malenkov, perceived as a moderate, wishing to reform the country while remaining true to the principles of Lenin and Stalin and seen as Stalin's unofficial successor and Vyacheslav Molotov, a fanatical admirer of Stalin and perceived as a "hardliner" and Stalin's "spiritual" successor.

After the Stalinist takeover and the political or physical elimination of our enemies. The Marshal of the Soviet Union, having kept his military and political positions, tried to organize a coup d'√©tat to stop us and set up a less authoritarian regime. We can always turn the tables by using the population and the KGB to spread false information to counter Zhukov.

After Zhukov's attempted coup, a trial will be held to try him for this inadmissible action. The problem is that we have just learned that he will try to escape into exile. The KGB is sent in urgently so that he can be arrested before that becomes worse.

Zhukov is stopped in extremis before he leaves the Soviet territory, forcing him to land in Minsk. Zhukov is thus brought back to $CAPITAL$, watched H24. At the time of the trial, Zhukov did not even attempt to defend himself and the jury returned its verdict. Zhukov was not sentenced to death, but was condemned to stay in his Dacha all his life and to be permanently watched by guards. The sentence was avoided because the former General was extremely popular in the army, among the population and even internationally, perceived as the one who defeated Fascism.

As Zhukov was flying abroad, our agents tried to stop him, but as he did not seem to want to cooperate, our pilots shot at the plane, making it land near the Polish border. The death of the ex-general shocked the whole world. Even if we say that his death was accidental, no one really believes it, theories are even starting to spread.

Horror! Georgy Zhukov managed to escape and went into exile in the United States and was welcomed by President Eisenhower. In addition to this, Zhukov tells about the conditions of life in the Soviet Union and of course it is not very advantageous for us. Our international reputation is completely stained.

The failed attempt to take power by the army, led by Zhukov, left an atmosphere of general suspicion. To remedy this, it seems that Secretary General is launching a Great Purge within the party and in all institutions. It remains to be seen how extensive this purge will be.

Trofim Lyssenko was a Soviet agricultural technician and was at the origin of a pseudo-scientific genetic theory, the "Michurinian genetics", especially promoted during the Stalinist period. Stalin especially supported Lyssenko to be able to eliminate his political opponents much more easily, especially since Lyssenko was a convinced Marxist-Leninist and did not hesitate to be overzealous. Now that Stalin is dead and his faction is still in power, we have to decide what to do with him, who has become much too cumbersome scientifically and even internationally.

The place of Stalin's cult in Soviet society after his death was predominant. However, a new moderate leader has come to power and can decide the fate of Stalin and his cult. It is possible to keep the status-quo by maintaining the Cult of Stalin, or to create a commission to evaluate Stalin's actions while valuing him, or to denounce him by restoring the truth.

With the coming to power of Malenkov, a reorganization of the planned economy of the Soviet Union will begin. Malenkov explained to the Central Committee that the aim of this reform is not to modify in depth the model imposed by Stalin, that is to say centered on the Heavy Industry, but to favor more one sector to answer better the needs of the population. However, a debate is taking place to know if it is necessary to favor more the Light Industry or the Consumer Goods.

Agriculture in the Soviet Union has always been a problem and has never really been a problem. However, Georgy Malenkov is the new person who will try to solve this thorny problem. The solution he advocated was, first, to reduce taxes for all peasants, then to increase the amount paid to kolkhozes by the state for grain and incentives for peasants to cultivate their private plots. Many members see this proposal as very costly and inefficient. Other members propose the mechanization of the farms to improve their productivity and others, finally, propose an immediate solution of buying grain abroad to avoid new famines or shortages.

Malenkov had also talked about the possibility for peasants to have their own plot of land for their own crops. This seems to become a reality as a decree will be issued soon, however, the Central Committee and Malenkov are still debating to put the limits of this proposal. Malenkov and his supporters would like to create targeted regions throughout the Soviet Union of Autonomous Farms whose primary goal is to do agriculture at the level to be able to feed more or less a maximum of people without waste. However, other, more radical members would like to introduce a Family Contract and start a generalized liberalization of agriculture throughout the Soviet Union.

Since the implementation of Malenkov's economic reforms, the standard of living of Soviet citizens has greatly improved, being able to enjoy products that were previously limited or non-existent for the average citizen. However, the country's economy is not doing as well as hoped but it has not deteriorated.

Although bureaucracy can be useful, its slowness and corruption have been proven. Thus, Malenkov wishes to improve this situation by implementing a reform aimed at the administration. However, some members of the party would like to limit this reform to avoid irritating the bureaucracy too much.

To the general surprise, Georgy Malenkov announced his resignation as General Secretary and Chairman of the Council of Ministers of the Soviet Union. The reasons he officially gave were that the reforms he had undertaken did not really correspond to the expected results and that he therefore admitted his mistakes. The unofficial reasons, however, are a bit more complicated. Malenkov's reforms did not really succeed in improving the economic situation of the country,  and even put it into debt, and angered a large part of the CPSU. So, before it was too late for him, Malenkov preferred to resign with honors rather than be ejected. Many candidates wanted to become General Secretary but two personalities stood out: Alexander Shelepin, seen as harder than his predecessor and in the continuity of Stalinism, and Leonid Brezhnev, perceived as more moderate and conciliatory.

Vyacheslav Molotov was throughout his life a zealous supporter of Joseph Stalin and was always loyal to him, even when Stalin arrested his wife for "treason". Now that Stalin is dead and Molotov has become the new leader of the Soviet Union, the question of what to do with the legacy is quite obvious to the new leader. However, the question is how to pay tribute to him. Maintaining the cult of Stalin is obvious, but Molotov hesitates between two choices: either building a Mausoleum for Stalin or, more original, creating a position solely for Stalin by naming him "Eternal Leader of the USSR".

Although Molotov took power, Malenkov still had an important place in the Central Committee and he demanded that a number of economic reforms be implemented. Although Malenkov argued that these reforms would remain faithful to the model set up by Stalin, it was mainly a question of privileging light industry to meet the needs of the Soviet population over heavy industry. Do we listen and apply, at least in part, Malenkov's reforms or do we maintain Stalin's model?

More and more people in the party are starting to say that the agriculture of our country has shortcomings and does not meet the needs of the population. To avoid shortages, or even new famines, some members propose the purchase of grain from abroad. However, many members propose to mechanize the farms in order to improve their productivity.

In the face of this attempt to seize power by the military, it has become obvious that the army must be gagged and remain loyal to the party only. One proposal, which may cause a scandal within the army, is to strengthen the position and powers of our political commissars so that the army will never again try to overtake us.

Although the Soviet Union and China are allies, more and more tensions are beginning to appear. Indeed, even if both countries have the same admiration for Stalin, the two countries do not necessarily have the same points of view on other subjects such as foreign policy, the management of the economy, the direction that the socialist camp should take, etc. The worst happened when a meeting was held in Romania and the Soviet and Chinese delegates started to insult each other and almost fight. This cannot be tolerated and more and more party members demand that China must submit to the Soviet Union for the sake of the socialist camp.

Mao has been summoned to $CAPITAL$, he is aware that we are going to demand something of him and he also suspects that it will revolve around our tensions. It remains to be seen how we wish to express our problems with China and Mao.

For some time now, although the USSR and China are allies and our admiration for Stalin remains the same, tensions are beginning to appear, whether from the strategic point of view of the Socialist Camp, foreign policy, management of the economy, etc., and at a meeting in Romania our delegations almost got into a fight. Today, the Soviet Union has summoned us and demanded our submission so that the latest events will never happen again and for the good of the Socialist Camp over that of the imperialists.

In the face of our attempt to bring Mao, and China by extension, to its senses. We have just learned that Mao has broken our Friendship Pact and that our alliance is worthless.

Cybernetics in the Soviet Union is a science that conscripted to control the transmission of information in various systems, whether machines, living organisms or society began in the 1940s. Under Stalin's rule, Cybernetics was considered a reactionary American pseudoscience to be denounced and mocked. However, despite this attitude towards this science, more and more party members are showing interest in this discipline, especially in the automation of the economy. Should we reintroduce Cybernetics and study this automation or maintain Stalin's decision.

Today Comrade Vyacheslav Molotov, General Secretary of the CPSU, died. For the Western world, he is a hard dictator, intellectually blocked and anchored in a certain worldview. However, even if his dream of creating a kind of supranational entity to encompass all the socialist states did not come true, he left behind a planned and automated economy.

Today Comrade Vyacheslav Molotov, General Secretary of the CPSU, died. For the Western world, he is a hard dictator, intellectually blocked and anchored in a certain worldview. However, even if his dream of creating some kind of supranational entity to encompass all the socialist states did not come true, he left the country in such a state that economic and political reforms will be necessary to try to save the Soviet Union.

On his 60th birthday in 1956, Zhukov received his fourth Hero of the Soviet Union award, making him the first person to receive this honor four times before Brezhnev awarded it to himself. He is thus Marchal of the Soviet Union and an important member of the Presidium of the Central Committee of the CPSU. In addition, he began to demand that the political agencies of the Soviet Army report to him before the Party. More and more Party members accused him of being a reformist and, even worse, a Bonapartist.

Faced with the reformist vision of the Marshal of the Soviet Union, Georgy Zhukov, and due to the fact that he is a very popular military man, a coup attempt is underway. They gathered most of the Stalinists, i.e. Molotov, Malenkov, Kaganovich, and so many others who would join them later, fearing Zhukov's takeover. They called a meeting in the Presidium to remove him from office. Although the majority of members were not present, the plotters represented the majority at that time. However, this coup was able to fail thanks to the support of the First Secretary of the Soviet Union, Nikita Khrushchev. It was enough to give the order and Khrushchev and his thousands of party members in $CAPITAL$ and throughout the country will march to help us.

In a few hours, the Marshal of the Soviet Union, Georgy Zhukov, has the honor of delivering the opening speech of the 21st Congress of the CPSU, which will decide for the next few years the economic and political direction of the country. Exceptionally, the party has offered a car to the Marshal to get to the meeting place. However, during the journey, a dull but audible noise began to be heard.

In the middle of the journey, in the middle of $CAPITAL$, an explosion can be heard and a certain panic in the allentour.A few hours later, the tragic news is reported to the population, the Marchal of the Soviet Union, the henchman of Fascism, has been killed in an attack described by the KGB, as terrorist, suspecting nationalist dissidents. Three days of mourning are decreed in the whole country and a new Marshal is appointed by the party and Nikita Khrushchev makes a tearful speech, knowing that he becomes the uncontested leader of the Soviet Union.

After arriving at the CPSU Congress in $CAPITAL$, the car explodes, killing the driver and some soldiers. The shock was total, both for the population and for the Marshal, who managed to escape death in a few minutes. Although an investigation was opened, the KGB concluded that it was a nationalist attack, the army suspecting that the party wanted to kill Zhukov because he was too troublesome.

Now that Zhukov's hands are more or less free, he can begin to undertake military reforms so that the country can defend itself against all forms of aggressors and make the army modern and efficient, if possible without the CPSU having a word to say about it.

The Novorossiysk, originally named Giulio Cesare, was an Italian battleship that was transferred to the Soviet Union in 1949. However, the ship was sunk by an old German mine in 1955, resulting in 608 deaths, and Marshal Zhukov took the opportunity to remove Nikolai Kuznetsov from his position as Admiral of the Soviet Union Fleet. One could continue to use this excuse to give less importance to the navy and thus privilege the army.

Today, Zhukov and the Central Committee met to implement the military reforms desired by the Marshal of the Soviet Union. The first question of the day, and it is a rather sensitive one, was the place of political commissars in the army. Zhukov never had them, considering that politics should not intervene in military strategies, and would like to get rid of them.

The next topic is to improve the quality of the Soviet army, several proposals are on the table. The first one is to reduce the number of soldiers, justified by the fact that these soldiers are not needed anymore since the end of the Second World War and that would allow to win money, the second one is to reduce the duration of the military service, which would allow to greatly improve the quality of the army, and finally, the one proposed by Zhukov, to make a combination of the two proposals. Or, of course, we can change nothing.

And finally, the last subject, an original proposal of Zhukov, that of transferring the authority of the Militsiya, a kind of police force under the USSR, under his authority so that the local security of the country is in the hands of people who already deal with national security. Of course, this displeases the party members who consider that the army would have too much power.

Faced with the incredible popularity of Marshal Georgy Zhukov, there was a revival of Russian nationalism in the entire Russian-speaking population. Nationalism of any kind has always been fought and suppressed by the party. Although nationalism has always existed in the Soviet Union, this rise in power is impossible to ignore and something must be done. However, some unscrupulous members propose that an arrangement be made with the nationalist movement so that it cannot harm the party or even fight other nationalists.

It is with great surprise that the Marshal of the Soviet Union learns that his ally, Nikita Khrushchev, is organizing a meeting with party members accusing Zhukov of being a dangerous general with too much ambition. However, the Marshal already had a lot of power and was well respected in the army and even among the population. Thus, Zhukov sent his army to $CAPITAL$ to make a show of force and Khrushchev was arrested in the middle of a speech. It remains to be seen whether one wishes to eliminate him by removing him from power or if one proceeds to a more spectacular elimination.

During a diplomatic visit to the United States, the Marshal of the Soviet Union, Georgy Zhukov, met the American President, Dwight D. Eisenhower. These two personalities met for the first time at the Potsdam Conference and quickly became friends, and the first half of this meeting gave rise to discussions about their memories in the post-war period. After a while, the President managed to talk to Zhukov about the Soviet economic system and compared it to the American one. The Marshal seems to have been very interested in the effects of liberalism. It remains to be seen whether the American President was convincing enough to make the Marshal change, at least partially, his economic system.

Although the Soviet Union has always had problems with its agriculture, it would seem that a solution must be found to avoid a new general shortage in the country. Some propose buying grain from abroad as an immediate solution, others propose increasing the productivity of the farms by mechanizing them, and finally, a third camp, much more radical, proposes to liberalize the farms with the creation of agricultural cooperatives in order to let the peasants manage their fields and production themselves.

The increasing accumulation of power in the hands of the military forced the CPSU to give the coveted title of General Secretary of the Party to the Marshal of the Soviet Union, Georgy Zhukov. Thus, it became increasingly common to name the leader Zhukov as "Secretary-Marshal". This is definitive, the party was subjugated and the military is in charge of all political and economic aspects of the country.

In December 1967, Georgy Zhukov suffered a severe stroke and was hospitalized almost immediately. However, despite the care provided, the stroke of the Secretary Marshal left him paralyzed on the left side, his speech became difficult and he could walk only with assistance, so it becomes impossible for him to lead this country properly. So, in a pre-recorded TV and radio address, the Secretary-Marshal announced his resignation and left the country in the hands of Dmitry Ustinov, a military man who had proven himself under his government and appealed to a large portion of the party.

A new meeting of the Central Committee will be held to determine the amount of the budget to be allocated to the different departments. However, the arrival in power of Dimitri Ustinov could change the situation for the military. Indeed, in addition to being a Marshal, Ustinov is a fervent supporter of the international struggle and has always asked for more money for the military so that they can defend the interests of the Soviet Union and even Communism.

During the period of Zhukov, the latter had implemented a liberalization of the economy, allowing the country to receive money easily and even the population to have more economic freedom. However, Ustinov and a large part of the CPSU wanted to return to the old model of planned economy, which would not please the population already used to this system.

With the increase of the budget obtained thanks to Ustinov, it is now possible to transfer this extra money to one of the branches of the army. We can either give more money to the army to equip it with the latest modern equipment to improve its quality, or we can give this money to the Navy to speed up recruitment and build up a huge fleet of ships.

The Space Race, started in 1957, was, in fact, a lost cause for the Soviet Union, despite great advances and achievements. Now, all this money injected to serve to help in our development and in the development of other socialist countries. Maybe we could stop this adventure and do something else with this money.

Today, Dmitri Ustinov, Marshal of the Soviet Union and General Secretary of the CPSU, died. Ustinov did little to try to improve the country's increasingly critical economic situation by favoring the military. His successor in this position, Sergei Sokolov, is considered his military successor but seems to have different ideas about politics.

Since the military took power, the question of whether to pursue the cause of Communism has arisen among some military personnel, wanting to assume the true nature of the state of the Soviet Union. However, this is a big risk and the party will not be pleased. Perhaps we should try to save the Soviet Union?

The Marshal of the Soviet Union and General Secretary of the CPSU, Sergei Sokolov, has convened the Politburo to find a solution to try to make reforms to try to save the Soviet Union from falling. The first topic discussed was whether Sokolov wanted to give more power to the Supreme Soviet to transform it into a real legislative power.

The next topic is the duration of the Conscription. It is impossible to consider a reduction of the conscription, as this would be contrary to the current military doctrine. However, we can go further and make military service compulsory for everyone, both men and women, and that it is a matter of survival of the Motherland.

A new reform is the question of the structure of the state, that is, whether Sokolov wants more control over the party and the state by effecting a recentralization, to change nothing or to grant more freedom to the different republics by transforming the USSR into a confederation?

The trade unions under the Soviet Union played a secondary role due to the fact that they were under the control of the state, however, since the military took power, Sokolov would like to abolish them altogether, considering that the state is already a good enough protector against the citizens. The conservative faction of the party would, of course, like to maintain the system as it is, while others, more reformist, would like to grant more trade union freedom by allowing opposition trade unions.

Since the military took power with Georgy Zhikov, the latter had put in place, under the influence of his friend and the American president, Dwight Eisenhower, a partially liberal economic reform, allowing the population to have their own business and the government to have easy money via taxes. However, when Dmitri Ustinov came to power, faced with growing wealth inequality among the population and increasingly visible anger in the party, the planned economy system had returned. Now, a part of the party and the army want to return to the Zhokov model. What should we decide?

We have been experiencing economic stagnation for the past few years and we need to address this problem. Part of the party and the army advises that we liberalize our economy in order to revitalize our economy while finding money easily. However, the other part of the party and the army are controlling, claiming that this problem of stagnation is in no way related to our economic system. We will have to decide what we want to do.

In recent years, especially since Sokolov came to power, the Soviet Union has become so militarized that its economy has begun to be oriented exclusively to the service of the military, and political reforms have taken place, but this has actually hardened the regime, giving it even less power than before. The world is concerned about the turn of events in the Soviet Union.
No reforms, economic or political, have taken place in the Soviet Union. Or at least, these reforms are only of facade but the problems which the USSR meets are always present. Will this be enough?

Moderate reforms were carried out in the Soviet Union in order to modernize the country, both politically and economically, but also to balance the power between the party and the military, which had become unavoidable. Maybe this will be enough?

With the coming to power of Gorbachev and the implementation of more liberal policies, such as Perestroika, the Brezhnev Doctrine is seen by the Soviet government as oppressive policy. Moreover, the Soviet Union no longer had the means to impose its will on the countries of Eastern Europe. In the face of this, we have the opportunity to implement a policy that would allow the Warsaw Pact countries to determine their own internal affairs. This policy already has a name: the Sinatra Doctrine, after the song "My Way" popularized by Frank Sinatra.

Very soon, a new government will be put in place, which means that there will be new Ministers. Among them, one position is of particular interest, that of Minister of Foreign Affairs.Indeed, the person who occupied this position is leaving for retirement soon, and depending on who will be this new minister, a new doctrine can be adopted and candidates have been selected.

The candidates for the posts of Ministers of Foreign Affairs are the following: Semyon Kozyrev, participant in the Potsdam Confederation, former ambassador to several countries and Vice-Minister of Foreign Affairs between 1966 and 1983, he is a very experienced member and adept at the policy implemented by Andrei Gromyko, which consists of Containment of the USA.Alexander Bessmertnykh, a moderate reformist, is a strong supporter of the rapprochement of the communist parties in Europe, he is a follower of the Pacific Coexistence. And Eduard Shevardnadze, a relatively young party member and part of the reformist faction that promotes the New Thinking Policy.

Now that Semyon Kozyrev has become the new Foreign Minister, it means that the Brezhnev Doctrine will be maintained. However, some members of the cabinet would like to modernize this doctrine, to make it a little more acceptable. A solution is already found, it would be enough to impose economic sanctions on the dissident countries, which would still allow to control this region.

Now that we have a new Minister of Foreign Affairs, it is now to change the Doctrine for the Warsaw Pact. Some would like to give more freedom of interpretation on Marxism, arguing that the Soviet Union does not have the monopoly of the right reading of Marx's works. Others would like to make the members of the Warsaw Pact equal, but this would make us lose influence in the region. And finally, others would like us to withdraw our military bases in these countries, in order to ease the situation in Europe and with the United States.

Since a certain relaxation in the promotion of Marxism-Leninism within the Warsaw Pact, more and more members in the party would officially like to have their own vision of Marxism promoted in the country. While many would like to put forward some of our characteristics, much like in China or even Romania, others would like to use this opportunity to strengthen the ideology of Marxism-Leninism in the party and in our society. Others, finally, warning of the risk that this could take and recalling the different tragedies of our block.

Today we learn with surprise that $FROMCOUNTRY$ has just proclaimed a new interpretation of Marxism, which makes it a new ideology. We will have to react to this. Some members do not see any problem with this new interpretation, others, even if they are not hostile to this new ideology, keep a certain distrust, and finally others, are completely opposed to it and would like to cut all links with them.

$CAPITAL$'s reconstruction projects already existed at the time of the Russian Empire, based on the examples of reconstruction of European cities such as Berlin or Rome. These first attempts were stopped because of the WWI, the 1917 revolutions and the Civil War. However, from 1920 onwards, the Soviet government began to think about rebuilding the city as the capital of the first socialist state in the world. During this period, some projects were born, but it was more a period of intensive discussions between "urbanists" and "ruralists". It was not until 1933 that these quarrels were stopped and a workshop was set up to study the issue, and 1935 that Stalin and Molotov approved the resolution "On the general plan of reconstruction of the city of $CAPITAL$". Although the plan was only partially implemented due to the resources, Stalin's ambitions and the WWII, the city had already started to change. With the death of Stalin and the rise to power of a new leadership, it is possible to resume the reconstruction of the city normally or to cancel it, claiming that the project was too elaborate and costly.

Despite the cancellation of the $CAPITAL$ reconstruction project and of such important monuments as the Palace of Soviets, the need for a building for the meetings of the Supreme Soviet and for the CPSU Congresses became more and more important. Soon, the project will be made public and even the $MONARCHTITLE$ is personally involved in the project to put this building directly in the Kremlin.

Despite the cancellation of the $CAPITAL$ reconstruction project, the construction site of the Palace of Soviets remains empty. This project had begun in February 1931 with the demolition of the Cathedral of Christ the Savior and the beginning of the work had begun in 1939 with the implementation of the Foundation Piles. However, with the beginning of the Great Patriotic War, the construction was interrupted, and worse, the steel structure was cut and used for the defense of the city and other purposes during the war. Since we have disavowed the Palace of the Soviets, we now have the choice of either rebuilding the Cathedral or turning it into an open-air pool.

By becoming a social democracy, more and more opinions and people, once suppressed or banned, are becoming more and more vocal. Since 1988, a public movement supported by the Orthodox Church wants to return the Cathedral of Christ the Savior to $CAPITAL$. We can allow it to be rebuilt, but that means we must remove the pool or, of course, keep the pool.

Since we decided to continue the project of reconstruction of the city of $CAPITAL$, one of the most emblematic monuments is the Palace of Soviets. This project started in February 1931 with the demolition of the Cathedral of Christ the Savior and the work began in 1939 with the laying of foundation piles. However, with the outbreak of the Great Patriotic War, construction was interrupted, and worse, the steel structure was cut up and used for the defense of the city and other purposes during the war. However, some people would like to do something less expensive, such as an open-air swimming pool or even rebuild the Cathedral of Christ the Savior.

The Stalinka was the name given to the building built under Stalin between 1930 and 1950. These apartments are of very good quality and very spacious, easily recognizable and generally did not rise more than 3 or 4 floors. This type of apartment requires a lot of time to work, because of, among other things, the detailed decoration style. Faced with the housing problem, the party members would like to at least keep this model but with less details, or even abandon this kind of apartment to create stantardized buildings.

In the project of reconstruction of the city, it was also planned to extend, to remake, entire streets inspired by European cities, like in Paris, but also to enlarge the Red Square. But this meant destroying buildings, historical monuments and monasteries. If we agree, we will have enough space to build a new building that was planned under Stalin.

With the permission to extend the streets of $CAPITAL$, we will be able to build one of the following buildings: The Palace of Technology, announced in 1933, was supposed to be located on the banks of the Moskva River. The building should have united all the scientists and technicians of $CAPITAL$ and was supposed to represent the Soviet industrial, technological, agricultural, transportation and communication achievements. The People's Defense Commissariat, announced in 1933, was supposed to be located on the Arbat Square and was to represent the power of the Red Army. The House of Books, announced in 1934 and supposed to be located on Pushkin Square in order to regroup all the publishing houses of the Union. And the Aeroflot Building, planned to be located at the Belorussky station, in homage to the aviator of the Great Patriotic War but above all to the rescuer of the Cheliuskin ship, which had sunk in the Arctic waters.

The Great Patriotic War caused a lot of losses, both military and civil, and in 1942 it was planned to build a monument to the defenders of $CAPITAL$ and it was suggested to erect it on the Red Square. Perhaps we can build this monument, but this time in the name of all victims of this war against fascism.

Although this led to internal debates at first, the decision to keep Lenin's body was made by the government in the year of his death in 1924. Although initially made of wood, the Mausoleum was finally built of red brick in 1929. As we continue the reconstruction of the city, we have the possibility, of course, to keep the building, or to build a bigger mausoleum, or even to build the project of Pantheon for all the dead of the important political personalities of the country. Although it was announced at the time of Stalin's death, it never materialized.

We are finally nearing the end of the reconstruction of $CAPITAL$ and it remains to settle the details. However, facing the amount of money we have spent, some members argue that it would be better to build a kind of wall around the city and to limit its access to outsiders as well, and that the inhabitants of the city cannot leave the city without a good reason. The city would undergo very little change, if not for the needs of the city. Should we accept this proposal that may cause controversy in the city.

The city was finally rebuilt, in the image that the government and the party wanted. It is possible, in view of this achievement, to decide to rename the city. Some, especially Stalinists, would like to give it Stalinodar, in order to pay tribute to Stalin. Although this name had been considered for a while, Stalin refused it, fearing that it would be some kind of joke on the part of his former adversaries (since he had noticed that most of the requests to change the name of the city came from former enemies). Others wanted to keep the name, of course, but another party wanted to rename it Sovietgrad, because the capital would represent the whole Soviet Union in the country and in the world.

Vladimir Zhirinovsky will begin to be known politically when Gorbachev, in 1990, removes the monopoly of power from the CPSU and allow other parties to be created and exist. Zhirinovsky created the Liberal Democratic Party of the Soviet Union, but he was soon suspected that the party was created with the KGB in order to serve the interests of the Soviet state. In the 1991 elections for the position of President of the RSFSR, he reached the 3rd position with 7.81% of the votes. During the August Coup, Zhirinovsky supported the Emergency Committee in public by insulting the democratic supporters, who lynched him. Zhirinovsky will be especially known in the world for his extreme and provocative positions, in particular his will to take back Alaska, to exterminate all the birds entering the Russian territory so that they can't transmit virus and etc.

Grigori Yavlinsky did not join the CPSU until 1984-1985, when he was admitted to the leadership of the Ministry of Labor and then the Council of Ministers. However, Yavlinsky began to make a political name for himself when he joined a committee with Leonid Abalkin on how to economically reform the Soviet Union. Grigori Yavlinsky was soon in favor of the rapid transition from a planned to a market economy. He will present his project called "500 Days Program" (originally named "Transition to the Market") under the leadership of Stanislav Shatalin. His project will get the support of Boris Yestlin, Gorbachev will be septic and Nikolai Ryzhkov, Prime Minister of the USSR, will openly repudiate him, threatening to resign if the project were to pass. In reality, after the fall of the Soviet Union, and the implementation of the "shock therapy" by Yestlin, based on Yavlinsky's plans, he will be considered by his opponents and by some economists, as an example of what not to do in an economic transition or even accused of economic illiteracy.

Alexander Lebed became known as the commander of the 106th Airborne Division and participated in the repression of interethnic uprisings, especially in the Caucasus, which usually ended brutally. During the August Coup, Lebed played an ambiguous but important role. Although he participated in the events, he eventually sided with the democrats, which allowed him to remain in the army and to be popular among the democrats. He left shortly afterwards to found his own party (first the Congress of Russian Communities and then the People's Republican Party of Russia) and soon became popular among the army and the Russian-speaking population, which some Western and Russian observers compared him to Pinochet and even Napoleon.

Aman Tuleyev started to be really interested in politics only from 1990 when he tried to become President of the RSFSR but will remain popular only in his fief, in Kemerovo. In 1991, he will openly support the August Coup and will start to take more importance later. Tuleyev became known for his hard-line stance on domestic policy but advocated a more flexible, even liberal, economic policy. Later, he would become known as a "Muslim communist" and would attract sympathy from some communist members.

Boris Yeltsin began to gain importance in politics when Gorbachev came to power with the recommendation of Egor Ligachyov, seeing him as a potential ally. Although he supported the Perestroika policy at the beginning, Yeltsin soon criticized Gorbachev as being too moderate. Yeltsin eventually became a rival to Gorbachev and the CPSU by becoming increasingly popular for his criticism of the party and by exacerbating the various nationalisms of the Soviet Union, even Russian nationalism. Even though the Soviet Union succeeded in reforming itself into a social democracy, Boris Yeltsin is considered by the communists to be a dangerous person and a potential destroyer of the country.

Alexander Yakovlev will play a big role in Gorbachev's reforms. Indeed, he was Gorbachev's main advisor and helped shape foreign policy by advocating a non-interventionist policy and helping to implement the Perestroika and Glasnost reforms, so much so that he was nicknamed the "godfather of Glasnost" and was the first Soviet politician to recognize the secret protocol of the Ribbentrop-Molotov Pact. However, his primary objective was never, unlike Gorbachev, to try to save the Soviet Union but to destroy the Soviet Union. This will be learned years later, being loved by the liberals, but hated by the communists but also by the Russian nationalists for his anti-nationalist positions.

Dmitri Vasilyev began to get involved in politics when he joined a historian's association, Pamyat, which became a monarchist, anti-Semitic and ultranationalist nationalist-orthodox organization the following year, advocating the restoration of the Russian Empire and the Romanovs. Now that he has come to power legally, nothing can stop him from realizing his dream!

Since the Cuban Missile Crisis, the United States has continued to implement a blockade against Cuba, even though it refuses to recognize this term. Since then, the Soviet Union and Cuba have remained allies, although there have been ups and downs. However, in recent times, some members have begun to question this economic support for Cuba. But, according to some influential members in the Politubro, they think that there may be a "poker move" to play against the United States by voluntarily provoking a diplomatic crisis. Cuba would have to agree to this first, of course.

An offer has been proposed to us by the Soviet Union, in fact, they claim that in order to "unblock the unjust economic situation" that the United States makes us suffer since the Cuban Missile Crisis. They propose us to put back missiles on our island in order to provoke a diplomatic crisis against them. Needless to say, many members of the party find this proposal dangerous, but others, who are in the minority, are tempted by the proposal, especially if it would stop the blockade.
We have just learned that the offer we made to put missiles on Cuba was refused. This was quite expected but we are still disappointed by this refusal.

Even if we had already observed strange activities on the island of Cuba, we have just learned via satellite images what we thought impossible. The Soviet Union is still trying to put missiles on Cuba! The entire country's General Staff is on alert and even though we have not yet told the public the truth, the population suspects that something is going on when they see the intensive military activities. Several solutions are being considered. The first one is to block Cuba completely, others propose the invasion of the island, even if it means provoking a nuclear war, some, more moderate, propose that we use the red phone to find a solution as soon as possible.

Our missiles on Cuba were discovered by the Americans via their satellites. However, in response to this, the Americans decided to block Cuba completely, which could lead to the downfall of the Cuban regime in the longer term. Perhaps it is high time to start negotiations between our two nations, although some extremists propose that it is better to attack American ships, considering their actions as sufficient justification to declare war on them.

Our missiles on Cuba were discovered by the Americans via their satellites. However, in response to this, the Americans decided to launch an invasion on Cuba. The situation is critical and many people propose nothing less than to launch nuclear missiles. However, some people ask that we call the USA via the red phone before it is too late.

Our two nations have managed to make contact and negotiations have begun in order to resolve this situation and avoid a potential nuclear war. Most of the diplomats and even the Minister of Foreign Affairs agreed that we should ask for a definitive end to the blockade on Cuba or else we could ask for the recovery of the western part of Berlin on behalf of East Germany.

In order to avoid a war between our two blocks, the Soviet Union proposed to stop the "Blockade" against Cuba. They argue that this policy towards Cuba is inhumane and a disgrace to the "land of freedom". This will be considered an important victory for the Communist Bloc if we accept, but if we refuse, it will mean war...

The Americans have agreed to lift the blockade against Cuba, in exchange, we agree to remove our missiles from the island as soon as possible. This is a great victory for the communist movement and in the anti-imperialist struggle. Although the means almost dragged the world once again into a nuclear winter, the people of Cuba and the Soviet Union sing the praises of our country and our leader.

The Americans have agreed to lift the blockade against Cuba, in exchange, the Soviet Union has agreed to withdraw their missiles from our island as soon as possible. This is a great victory for the communist movement and in the anti-imperialist struggle. Although the means almost dragged the world into a nuclear winter once again, we have freed ourselves from the grip of the American tyrant, all thanks to communism and the Soviet Union.

Since Grigory Yavlinsky came to power, it is now possible for him to implement the "500-day program". The program contained an economic doctrine which, according to its authors, consists in passing from a planned economy to a market economy and openly capitalist, in less than 2 years. The project met many opponents, naturally, from the communists, but also from economists who considered that such a transition could not be done so quickly, especially in a population in which, in a good majority, did not know the principle of labor contract, did not really have concrete knowledge of private property or even business. However, if the project is to be carried out, the President says that it will be done in several clear steps.

Since the 500-day program was launched, the daily life of the Soviet population has already been transformed, with the appearance of some things more and more paid. However, it is a matter of passing a new stage, the privatization of state property, which means both state-owned enterprises and land or housing that the population must buy. However, even within the government, members are arguing about how fast this privatization should be done. Some members would like a gradual privatization in order not to lose too much control and to make sure that the assets are in good hands and as fair as possible, while other members argue that the urgency of the situation requires that the privatization be done very quickly in order for the program to be successful.

A new step has been taken in the 500 Days Program: the liberalization of prices. This means that the state no longer has control over price setting and that this is accompanied by a thorough reform of the Gosbank, the Central Bank of the Union. From now on, the Gosbank will have to play a commercial role as can be observed in other banks in Western countries.

Today, in order to continue the 500 Days Program, a new step will be taken with the signing of a future treaty between the different republics, and future countries, of the Union. Indeed, in order to give a greater freedom, the government plans a massive decentralization of the institutions of the Union. Based in part on Western Europe, Grigori Yavlinsky wishes to give a quasi independence to the different republics of the Union, transforming them into quasi-countries. However, it remains to be seen to what extent his countries will have their independence. Will they be allowed economic freedom or will they be given other rights such as the possibility of having their own army, their own laws... In short, a greater political freedom.

Today, the government has just announced the end of the 500 Days Program, this was accompanied by the last reforms aimed at properly regulating the Soviet economic market without, theoretically, the state having to intervene. Only time will tell if these reforms will be sufficient to improve the economic situation of the country.

Since the implementation of the 500 Days Program and because of bad decisions or bad execution of the reforms, the population and even the different governors of the country, both in the RSFSR and in other countries, show discontent and demand new reforms. Indeed, while local governors complain that Moscow still has too much of a presence, the population, especially the communists, complain that the management of the country's resources is in the hands of oligarchs and that inequalities are increasing. We will have to decide what to do, maintain the status quo or give more freedom?

With the coming to power of Zhirinovsky, he had promoted during his campaign the Russian nationalism and had repudiated the other nationalists. Now that he is in power, Zhirinovsky has the opportunity to actively promote Russian culture throughout the Union. This will, of course, trigger a strong reaction among the general population.

During his presidential campaign, Vladimir Zhirinovsky promised to bring Alaska back under our banner. Now Zhirinovsky is about to send a message to the American President asking for the purchase of Alaska for a large sum of money. Needless to say, if we do this, the US is unlikely to agree to this request.

Today, we have just received a request, more than surprising, since the Russians have asked to buy back the lands of Alaska, arguing that it is a legitimate land of their country and that it is their right to take back these lands. What do we do...?

One of the proposals advocated by Vladimir Zhirinovsky was to take over the territories formerly held by Russia. Among these territories were the territories that the Russian Empire had settled in the north of present-day Iran, with the aim of creating a kind of security zone for the country. Today, Zhirinovsky will certainly send a request to Iran, do we want to claim "just" the north of the country or do we want to ask for the submission of the country under our domination?

Today, we have just received an unusual request from the Russians. Indeed, they ask us that we "return" them all the north of the country so that it can with a kind of security zone between us and them. If we refuse this offer, it will certainly mean war between us and them.

Since Vladimir Zhirinovsky came to power, he started to want more and more power for the position of President. This has obviously caused more and more conflicts between the supporters of the President and the communists and democratic parliamentarians of the Congress of People's Deputies. In the face of all this unrest, we still have a chance to avoid a major political crisis. Should we make some concessions to the communists?

During the week, President Zhirinovsky once again appeared before the Congress of People's Deputies to request an extension of his powers, which was denied. Zhirinovsky left the hall insulting the parliamentarians as "parasites of the nation". Since then, violent demonstrations have taken place in the capital and even elsewhere in the country. Faced with his internal problems, the President declared a State of Emergency in the whole country. This was the last straw for the parliamentarians and the Congress of People's Deputies rejected the President's edit and voted by a majority to dismiss the President and an interim President was elected instead. This was Alexander Rutskoy, a person considered sufficiently trustworthy by the parliamentarians and, of course, a communist. Communist and pro-parliamentary supporters, as well as liberals, gathered at the House of Soviets and began to raise barricades as a show of force. Should we leave or should we confront?

Since the government has decided to go into business, we will have to find allies. The first group that could support us are the Soviet nationalists, but we will have to promise them to restore a regime, at least similar to the one that existed before Gorbachev's reforms. The second group are the Russian nationalists, in exchange for which, we will have to set up a more personal regime and praise the Russian or even Slavic cultureAnd the last one is the Monarchists, in exchange for which the Romanov family will have to be restored to the throne of the Russian Empire. With whom do we want to form an alliance?

Tensions are rising and more and more people are gathering around the House of Soviets. According to our latest information, the KGB allied with them and gave military equipment to the opponents and offered their services to counteract us. In order to restore order, the President has ordered law enforcement and our allies to attack the building.

Despite the violent clashes between our supporters and the opponents, the latter managed to counteract us. The opponents are already claiming victory and are waiting for the next orders from the Parliamentarians and their President to decide what to do. Our forces are still too weak to counter them and we cannot wait for what they will do.

The opposition forces have failed to stop and the House of Soviets is being bombed, it is only a matter of time before the parliamentarians give up. The fighting was hard, we almost entered the civil war, but now, although the world was shocked by our actions, the situation has been stabilized.

Their President, supported by communist and democrat parliamentarians, has just announced to his supporters the seizure of the Kremlin and to make our government definitively fold. The opposition is getting into their vehicle, armed by the KGB and by shields taken by our law enforcement agencies. On the way, citizens cheered them with red flags in the windows. Our security forces and supporters quickly organized themselves at strategic points to prevent them from attacking the President's residence. The clash of the two sides is even more violent and, for the moment, neither side has the advantage. Some supporters have proposed that the President go into exile rather than submit to them.

Their President, supported by communist and democrat parliamentarians, has just announced to his supporters a counter-intuitive decision: to stay put. If many people do not understand the decision, it is to put pressure on the government in order to gain time. Newspapers from all over the world are commenting on the situation in our country. Worse, the population is starting to have more and more sympathy towards them and are giving the opposition all they can to maintain their morals. We don't have much of a choice anymore, either we try to establish contact with them or, as some supporters propose, the President goes into exile.

In the midst of all this chaos, a helicopter flew across Moscow and a few minutes later it was announced on the radio that the hostilities were over. The population has just learned that President Zhirinovsky has gone into exile to Finland. The opposition has won a great victory, the event is already compared to October 1917, when the communist forces, with the help of Trotsky and the Kronstadt sailors managed to overthrow the liberal power of that time.

While the last resistances of the pro-President supporters surrender. A crowd of people entered the Kremlin and the President's residence to arrest him. However, when they enter the door, they find only the lifeless body of Zhirinovsky, with a pistiolet in his hand. The news is announced on the radio and the situation calms down. The opposition won a great victory, the event is already compared to October 1917, when the Communist forces, with the help of Trotsky and the Kronstadt sailors, managed to overthrow the then liberal power. But for supporters of the former president, Zhirinovsky is seen as a kind of martyr, another victim of communism.

While the last resistances of the pro-President supporters surrender. A crowd of people entered the Kremlin and the President's residence to arrest him. Opponents arrived in the President's office and arrested Zhirinovsky, who was taken away and will certainly be tried for treason and "disturbance of the nation". The opposition won a great victory, the event is already compared to October 1917, when the Communist forces, with the help of Trotsky and the Kronstadt sailors, managed to overthrow the then liberal power. But the President continues, despite everything, to agitate his partisans.

Despite the balance of power, our supporters succeeded in pushing back the pro-parliamentary forces. It is up to us to decide what to do from now on. Either we decide to take advantage of their weakened forces and counterattack, or we decide not to take the risk and call for the start of negotiations.

While the last resistances of the pro-President supporters surrender. A crowd of people entered the Kremlin and the President's residence to arrest him. However, while trying to open the door, the opposition is greeted by bullets. The opposition returned fire and after several seconds, which seemed like minutes, President Zhirinovsky was shot. The news is announced on the radio and the situation calms down. The opposition won a great victory, the event is already compared to October 1917, when the Communist forces, with the help of Trotsky and the Kronstadt sailors, managed to overthrow the then liberal power. But for supporters of the former president, Zhirinovsky is seen as a kind of martyr, another victim of communism.

The camps met a few days later in a neutral place to find a solution to the conflict. The opponents are in an advantageous position and their conditions are as follows: President Zhirinovsky and his government must resign and the parliament must take power permanently. It is either that or the continuation of the conflict.

With the victory of President Zhirinovsky, the powers will be extended and the opponents will soon be charged with treason and "disturbance of the nation". However, those who have supported us during this period are coming to the President to ask him to honor his promises. What should we do?

With the victory of Lebed in the last elections, the latter, with the broad support of the army and part of the population, Lebed has the opportunity to take advantage of his popularity rating to start taking more and more control in the country. Either that, or to continue to respect the democratic process.

Now that the decision has been made, the first step in controlling the country will be to gain control of the various republics of the Union. For this, the idea would be to liquidate almost all local leaders and replace them with army officers loyal to Lebed.

Although tensions still existed between the different peoples, because of our actions, there was an explosion of separatist tensions. We must act quickly, before it is too late, or we use our armies to brutally repress them, but we will be frowned upon internationally. Or we use the KGB to eliminate the various nationalist leaders and repress the most radical of them.

Since the end of communism and the establishment of a more democratic regime, public order is no longer as secure and delinquency, once a vestige of the past, has exploded and bandits are organizing throughout the country. These people are easily recognizable, with their Italian raspberry-colored jackets, their gold watches, their imported vehicles... The worst thing is that even the youth want to become like them. We have to act quickly and fortunately for us there was an important event in Moscow. Indeed, one of these "New Russians" had the mistake to attack a member of the Thieves in the Law, the Russian mafia born in Stalin's gulag. We can use this opportunity either to disguise ourselves and eliminate them radically, or to let the Thieves in the Law do their job... but helping them anyway.

Today, a minor event is taking place, but it is expected by a part of the local population of Mount Sayan. Indeed, a new sky track has been opened bearing the name of the leader. In order to go faster, Lebed was advised to go there by helicopter.

Once the inauguration was over, President Alexander Lebed took off in his helicopter but died in a crash due to a collision with a electric line. The cause of the accident was an inexperienced new pilot, a non-updated map and bad weather conditions. His death is experienced as a tragedy by a large part of the population but not by the oligarchs. Indeed, Alexander Lebed had promised upcoming measures to improve the daily life of Russians and to purge corruption. There is even a conspiracy theory that it was the oligarchs and Lebed's rivals who organized all this.

Although Alexender Lebed is continuing to liberalize the country's economy gradually. A government meeting is being held to determine whether the state should privatize economic sectors, considered essential by some, such as electricity, oil, etc. Does the state still maintain some control over these activities even though partial privatization may take place, or is this left to the oligarchs in the name of a "healthy economy"?

More and more, the powers given to the different republics started to decrease. This is explained by the fact that Lebed's attention to transforming the republics into an authority means that the local leaders will become mere governors and that any national or even regional decisions can only be made if Moscow, especially Lebed, is willing. This is also accompanied by an intensive anti-corruption campaign.

Although Lebed always considered himself a nationalist, he never rejected the Soviet Union, especially its emblematic figure, Lenin. Thus, there always existed a certain form of Soviet nationalism in society, that is to say, the recognition of a form of national super-identity around the Soviet Union without rejecting the different nationalities en bloc. Thus, we have the choice to promote Soviet nationalism or to promote Russian nationalism and provoke discontent... especially among non-Russians.

President Alexander Lebed is in his 70s and the weight of power is beginning to be felt by the public. Thus, Lebed will soon announce his retirement, but will the President announce an election in order to respect the democratic process, or will he look for a successor?

Although Brezhnev's health was always a concern, he managed to govern well even though it was not always easy. However, last night, the Secretary General suffered a stroke with serious consequences.
